title: Brexit deal given fatal blow as Angela Merkel rejects Boris’s plan
text:
Boris Johnson has been given the cold shoulder by EU leaders (Picture: Getty)

Downing Street claims Brussels has made it ‘essentially impossible’ for Boris Johnson to get a new Brexit divorce deal.

A source at Number 10 said talks were close to officially breaking down following an early morning phone call between Boris Johnson and Angela Merkel.

The German chancellor is said to have made clear that a deal would only be possible if Northern Ireland were to stay in the Customs Union.

Downing Street called it a ‘clarifying moment’ and said this meant that a Brexit deal would never be possible with the EU.

Labour accused the Tories of a ‘cynical attempt to sabotage the negotiations’ and demanded Parliament unite and step in to stop us crashing out in three weeks’ time.

While European Council president Donald Tusk accused Mr Johnson of jeopardising the future security of the EU and the UK and indulging in a ‘blame game.’

German Chancellor Angela Merkel is said to have demanded that Northern Ireland remain in the customs union (Picture: Getty)

Speaking after the 8am phone call between Mr Johnson and the German leader, the Number 10 source said: ‘The call with Merkel showed the EU has adopted a new position.

Advertisement

‘She made clear a deal is overwhelmingly unlikely and she thinks the EU has a veto on us leaving the Customs Union.

‘Merkel said that if Germany wanted to leave the EU they could do it no problem but the UK cannot leave without leaving Northern Ireland behind in a customs union and in full alignment forever.

‘She said that Ireland is the government’s special problem and Ireland must at least have a veto on NI leaving.

‘Merkel said that it must stay in full alignment forever, but that even this would not eliminate customs issues.

‘It was a very useful clarifying moment in all sorts of ways.

‘If this represents a new established position, then it means a deal is essentially impossible not just now but forever.

‘It also made clear that they are willing to torpedo the Good Friday Agreement.’

Ms Merkel has yet to comment on this leak but political commentators in Europe said this did not sound like either her approach or her usual use of language.

Meanwhile Donald Tusk, the President of the European Council, warned Mr Johnson that ‘what’s at stake’ over Brexit ‘is not winning some stupid blame game.’

He added: ‘At stake is the future of Europe and the UK as well as the security and interests of our people.

‘You don’t want a deal, you don’t want an extension, you don’t want to revoke, quo vadis?’

The main issue is the border on the island of Ireland (Picture: AFP)

The main focus is on how to replace the so-called Irish backstop – the policy negotiated by Theresa May and the EU to prevent a hard border on the island of Ireland.

Advertisement

Advertisement

The Good Friday peace agreement, which brought an end to 40 years of conflict, made clear that the border between Northern Ireland and the Republic needed to remain open.

Keeping Northern Ireland in the Customs Union – meaning they followed EU trade rules – would keep the border open.

But, it would see part of the UK subject to different laws which is unacceptable to Mr Johnson and his allies, the DUP party in Northern Ireland.

Mr Johnson claimed his new blueprint to replace the Irish backstop represented a ‘big step forward and a compromise.’

However, he has not released many details but said both sides would need to commit to never introducing checks on the Irish border.

The EU sees this as an unacceptable loss of control and said the plan does not represent the basis for a new Brexit settlement.

The EU Commission even asked if there was a mistake in the text sent by Mr Johnson’s team.

European Council President Donald Tusk has accused Boris Johnson of a ‘stupid blame game’ (Picture: AFP)

Labour said Mr Johnson’s new deal was ‘never credible’ and accused the Tories of ‘sabotaging’ negotiations.

Shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer has now called on Parliament to unite to prevent ‘this reckless government crashing us out of the EU.’

As the clock ticks down, a new ‘Brexit readiness document’ is set to be published later today.

No-deal planning chief, Michael Gove, will detail all the preparations that have been made in case we crash out of the bloc.

Advertisement

Mr Johnson is still adamant the UK will leave on October 31, despite a law by rebel Tories and opposition groups making a no-deal Brexit illegal.

Parliament is set to be prorogued later today and will open again with the Queen’s Speech on Monday.

There are now just nine days before the crunch Brussels summit – which is the deadline set by the House of Commons for Mr Johnson to come up with a deal.

Tory sources have said Mr Johnson might even boycott next week’s summit.

Meanwhile EU diplomats have suggested leaders could use the summit to instead discuss another Brexit extension, despite the fact Mr Johnson has ruled out asking for one.
